stories.headline: Republicans seek tax cut for 1.6M in Wisconsin
stories.summary: About 1.6 million Wisconsinites could benefit from a proposed lower income tax bracket under a $1.3 billion tax cut plan approved by Republicans. The plan aims to expand the state's second-lowest tax bracket, impacting income taxes for many married couples and single filers by capping certain tax brackets. GOP leaders describe it as a meaningful tax cut for many Wisconsin residents.

stories.headline: GOP special ed plan pares back Evers' proposal
stories.summary: Republican lawmakers propose to increase funding for special education by $229 million over the next two years, a figure lower than Governor Tony Evers' $901 million proposal. The GOP plan includes a reimbursement rate increase to 37.5% by 2026-27, less than the 60% proposed by Evers. Republicans argue the current plan keeps Wisconsin's rate high in national ranking, while Democrats push for more funding to support students with disabilities.

stories.headline: IRAN LAUNCHES COUNTERSTRIKES
stories.summary: Iran's state media reported launching two waves of missile strikes on targets in Israel on June 13, following Israeli military attacks. There are claims of downed Israeli warplanes and no immediate official confirmation on casualties. The escalation follows a warning from Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei that attacks will persist without reprieve, as Israel continues strikes in the region.

stories.headline: St. Petersburg ends private development deal for marina
stories.summary: St. Petersburg city is ending negotiations with Safe Harbor Marinas to redevelop the downtown marina and will now handle redevelopment independently to keep the waterfront public. This decision aligns with community hopes to maintain public waterfront access.

stories.headline: Lawmakers agree not to fund DeSantis’ Hope Florida call line
stories.summary: Florida legislative leaders decided not to spend $2 million requested by Governor Ron DeSantis to fund the Hope Florida call line, critical to his program aiding Floridians off government assistance. The call line has come under legislative scrutiny and is central to connecting people with services.

stories.headline: Israel, Iran trade blows
stories.summary: Israel launched blistering attacks on Iran's nuclear and military sites, killing top generals and scientists, after Iran retaliated with missiles on Israel. The conflict highlights ongoing regional tensions, with concerns over possible escalation and international security risks.

stories.headline: Can Florida drivers run over protesters without consequence? What the law says
stories.summary: Following protests in Los Angeles and Florida against President Trump's immigration crackdown, questions emerged about drivers hitting protesters. Florida's law does not criminally prosecute drivers due to the 'stand your ground' defense, prompting debate on enforcement and public safety.

stories.headline: Florida protest organizers are preparing for busy few days as LA unrest unfolds
stories.summary: As immigration demonstrations are scheduled throughout the weekend, Florida protest organizers are cautiously preparing with increased safety measures. They aim to maintain peaceful protests despite the tension caused by events in Los Angeles and nationwide immigration actions.

stories.headline: State in a hurry on protest training
stories.summary: After Gov. Greg Abbott ordered the deployment of more than 5,000 Texas National Guard troops ahead of mass protests against President Donald Trump, internal memos obtained by the Austin American-Statesman reveal that military leaders are scrambling to find and train enough personnel for the mission. The state military department pulled 2,500 National Guard soldiers who had been assigned to Abbott's border security mission, Operation Lone Star, to prepare for protest control and de-escalation training on a rushed timeline. Guard members have expressed concerns about the scope and scale of the deployment, which is much larger than previous responses to protests, including a 1,000-troop deployment in 2020 after George Floyd's murder by police. The soldiers spoke on condition of anonymity because they are not authorized to speak to the media.

stories.headline: Trump orders restoration of Hood name to Fort Cavazos
stories.summary: Two years ago, Fort Hood in Central Texas was renamed Fort Cavazos to honor Gen. Richard E. Cavazos, the nation's first Hispanic four-star general. However, President Donald Trump has now ordered the restoration of the original names of seven military bases named after Confederate generals, including Fort Cavazos which will revert back to Fort Hood. The move is seen as politically motivated and has sparked debate. Fort Cavazos was originally named for Confederate Gen. John Bell Hood but was renamed to honor Col. Robert B. Hood, a decorated war hero. The restoration decision is part of a federal law requiring Confederate names to be removed from military installations but allowing soldiers to keep the same surnames.

stories.headline: APD chief promises restraint ahead of protest
stories.summary: Austin Police Chief Lisa Davis pledged that officers would exercise more restraint in dealing with agitators ahead of an anti-Trump protest Saturday. Referencing past excesses during 2020 Black Lives Matter protests, Davis promised no repeat of excessive force that caused injuries. The Austin Police Department faced criticism and legal cases over its use of force during the 2020 protests, with Travis County District Attorney Jose Garza presenting numerous use-of-force cases. The chief's comments come amid efforts to ensure safer and more measured crowd control at upcoming demonstrations.

stories.headline: Israel hits nuke sites in Iran, kills top generals
stories.summary: Israel launched blistering attacks on Iran's nuclear and military structures on Friday, deploying warplanes and drones to strike multiple sites. The attacks targeted facilities linked to Iran's nuclear program and killed top generals and scientists, aimed at slowing down Iran's ability to produce nuclear weapons. The strikes involved ballistic missiles on Israel and explosions near Jerusalem. These attacks signal escalating tensions and raise concerns about the possibility of all-out war and greater upheaval in the Middle East.

stories.headline: Love, cancer and pregnancy
stories.summary: A couple's choice to start a family reflects the challenges faced by a generation encountering illness at earlier ages. Tanner Martin was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer but hoped to live long enough to meet his daughter. The story highlights the emotional and medical journey of balancing family planning and cancer treatment.

stories.headline: Kennedy’s panel overhaul sows doubts over vaccine availability
stories.summary: The overhaul of the federal immunization panel by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has created uncertainty about vaccine availability and recommendations. The new panel and CDC staff have differing views on scientific and medical data, raising concerns about vaccine approval and availability for Americans. Officials say changes could impact evidence-based decision-making and trust in vaccine processes.

stories.headline: Army roiled by political turmoil ahead of its birthday
stories.summary: The U.S. Army is facing political turmoil as President Donald Trump criticized the Army leadership in North Carolina. Despite established military norms, Trump questioned the loyalty of soldiers, affecting morale among defense officials and soldiers. The partisan divide and ongoing political disputes have raised concerns about the Army's nonpartisan stance and unity ahead of its birthday.

stories.headline: Museum director quits amid standoff
stories.summary: Kim Sajet, director of the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery, resigned following a standoff with the Smithsonian Institution about staffing decisions. Sajet left her role two weeks after President Donald Trump claimed she was fired, though the Institution stated only its secretary could hire or fire museum leaders. Sajet was praised for expanding the gallery's collection and leadership during her 12 years.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates, with no end in sight
stories.summary: Iran unleashed a barrage of ballistic missiles at Israel, targeting military leaders and nuclear scientists, in response to Israeli strikes that killed top Iranian figures. Israel intercepted most missiles but damage was reported. Israeli and Iranian officials accuse each other of crossing 'red lines' amid an escalating conflict. Experts warn that the campaign could lead to a broader regional conflict, with no clear resolution in sight.

stories.headline: County recorder sues to ‘reclaim legal authority’ to run his office
stories.summary: Maricopa County Recorder Justin Heap filed a lawsuit to assert his authority to run his office independently of the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors and require them to pay for equipment and staff. The suit seeks a court order to compel the board to cover costs related to elections, voter registration, and document recording. The agreement with his predecessor significantly limited Heap's operational control.

stories.headline: President admits pain of migrant crackdown
stories.summary: President Donald Trump acknowledged that his aggressive immigration crackdown is negatively affecting farmers and the hospitality industry. He indicated that changes are coming and said 'common sense' policies will help farmers, hospitality, and leisure industries. Trump emphasized that worksite raids by ICE are hurting good workers and promised an order to help these industries soon.

stories.headline: Iran launches waves of missiles at Israel
stories.summary: Iran launched three waves of missiles at targets in Israel on June 13 amid escalating conflict. Israel intercepted over 100 rockets but some damage and injuries were reported. Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei declared the attacks a response to Israel initiating a war and vowed no retaliation attacks without grave consequences. The U.S. military helped shoot down Iranian missiles and a U.S. official confirmed no authorization to speak publicly.

stories.headline: Missiles Fly Across The Middle East
stories.summary: A wave of coordinated airstrikes took place in Tehran, Iran, following several missile attacks in the region. Israel launched attacks on Iran's key nuclear sites but missed fuel stockpiles. The assault has escalated tensions in the Middle East, with Iran retaliating and increasing fears of larger conflicts.

stories.headline: In Los Angeles, a Referendum On How the U.S. Views Protest
stories.summary: Demonstrations in Los Angeles protesting the Trump administration's immigration crackdown were marked by a quiet curfew and incidents of violence including a man firing a handgun into jewelry stores. The protests highlighted deep divisions over immigration policies and the right to protest, raising concerns about safety and civil rights.

stories.headline: Celebrating Army in Midst of an Identity Crisis
stories.summary: The US Army marked its 250th birthday amid turmoil caused by ongoing social unrest and debates about the army's role. Criticism from protesters and political leaders has led the Army to reconsider its public image and future direction as it navigates challenges like recruitment and internal morale.

stories.headline: 4 Men Escape ICE Detention During Unrest
stories.summary: Four men escaped an immigration detention center in Newark amid riots and violence caused by an uprising against poor conditions and lockdown at the facility. The unrest involved detainees smashing windows and causing chaos, which came after protests against detentions and deportations.

stories.headline: Democrats See Mayoral Race As Road Map
stories.summary: The New York City mayoral race has become a significant focus for Democratic politicians aiming to find a moderate pragmatist as a candidate. With prominent figures like Andrew M. Cuomo and Assemblyman Zoran Mamdani showcasing different approaches, the contest could signal a pathway for future Democratic leadership and political strategy in the city and beyond.

stories.headline: Clearer path nears for gun offenders to buy firearms
stories.summary: The Illinois General Assembly has passed a measure to make it easier for people who have been arrested for carrying guns illegally to obtain a state firearm permit that would allow them to own firearms. This bipartisan bill, marking a rare instance of agreement between Democrats and Republicans, removes obstacles created by the previous requirement for offenders.

stories.headline: 'I'm going kicking and screaming' - Women desperately await kidney donors
stories.summary: Katie Pappas, a 40-year-old teacher from northwest suburban Timber Trails Elementary, shares her struggle as she waits for a kidney donation while managing dialysis. She expresses frustration with the lengthy wait times and hopes for a living donor. Pappas is part of the 3,500 Illinoisans awaiting a kidney transplant, highlighting the critical need for organ donors.

stories.headline: Iran launches a barrage in retaliation for Israeli strikes
stories.summary: After Israeli strikes on Iran's nuclear and military structures, the United Arab Emirates reported Iran launching ballistic missiles into Israel. The attacks led to civilian casualties and explosions in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. The escalating conflict includes missile launches and security concerns in the region, with Israel and Iran trading fire and increasing tensions.

stories.headline: 7-PLUS YEARS FOR 'CORRUPT' MADIGAN
stories.summary: Michael J. Madigan, former Illinois House Speaker, has been sentenced to over seven years in prison for corruption charges. Madigan, 83, expressed remorse in court but did not admit guilt on multiple corruption charges. The court levied a maximum $2.5 million fine for abuse of power. Madigan's sentencing marks a significant moment in Illinois politics, with legal consequences for long-standing political misconduct.

stories.headline: Trump pushes for Iran nuclear deal
stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated there was "still time" to make a deal over the country's nuclear program following an Israeli attack on Iranian nuclear sites. Despite the significant damage, Trump urged for a diplomatic solution and praised Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for his leadership in confronting Iran's nuclear ambitions. The United States supported Israel’s actions but emphasized it was unaware of the specifics of the strikes beforehand. The Trump administration remains engaged amid ongoing tensions in the region.

stories.headline: Southside Community Center’s celebration returns
stories.summary: The Southside Community Center is preparing for its annual Juneteenth celebration on June 14, highlighting culture, freedom, and pride. The event, running from noon to 6 p.m., features live musical performances, vendors, and artists. The celebration honors African American history and commemorates the emancipation of slaves, with music, food, and dancing playing key roles. More information about the event is available on the Southside Community Center’s social media pages.

stories.headline: Stefanik grills Hochul
stories.summary: At a contentious House hearing, Rep. Elise Stefanik questioned Gov. Kathy Hochul over 'sanctuary' policies related to undocumented immigrants. Hochul, one of three Democratic governors subpoenaed, faced tough questions and criticism for state policies limiting cooperation with federal agencies on immigration enforcement. The hearing, spearheaded by Republicans, aimed to scrutinize sanctuary policies and featured exchanges about Hochul's handling of a violent crime case involving an undocumented immigrant. Stefanik's questioning was seen as a preparatory move for a potential gubernatorial challenge in 2026.

stories.headline: Des Plaines family mourns kin who were among 240 victims of Air India crash
stories.summary: A family from Des Plaines is mourning the loss of relatives who were among the 240 victims of the Air India crash, reflecting on the enduring impact of the tragedy on affected families.

stories.headline: NORTHWESTERN STUDENT SET TO GRADUATE AS HIS PARENTS ARE FACING DEPORTATION
stories.summary: A Northwestern University student is on track to graduate while his parents are facing deportation, highlighting the personal challenges and complexities faced by immigrant families within the educational system and immigration policies.

stories.headline: SPEAKER OF THE BIG HOUSE
stories.summary: Michael Madigan, former Illinois House Speaker, has been sentenced to 7½ years in prison and fined $2.5 million in a historic public corruption case, marking the downfall of one of Illinois' most powerful politicians from the S.W. Side Democrat faction.

stories.headline: John C. Reilly to bring Mr. Romantic alter ego to Steppenwolf this fall
stories.summary: Actor John C. Reilly will star as the character Mr. Romantic in a new production at Steppenwolf Theatre this fall, promising audiences a unique and engaging theatrical experience.

stories.headline: Iran sends missiles at Israel
stories.summary: Iran launched three waves of missile attacks targeting Israel, causing fires and injuries. Israel responded with airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites and military bases. The U.S. military aided in shooting down some missiles. Iranian Supreme Leader Khamenei affirmed Iran's stance against a war but vowed to continue attacks if attacked. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu emphasized Israel's determination to survive amid escalating conflict.

stories.headline: 'THESE KIDS ARE DISPOSABLE' Mexico's cartels recruit children, then they groom them into killers
stories.summary: Mexican drug cartels recruit children as young as 12, grooming them into killers to serve the cartels' violent operations. The article recounts the story of a former child recruit named Sol, who was later addicted to methamphetamine and imprisoned. Experts confirm child recruitment is a deliberate strategy by cartels to exploit vulnerabilities and strengthen their ranks, despite the deadly consequences for these youngsters.

stories.headline: No prison for teen in fatal crash
stories.summary: An 18-year-old who caused a fatal crash while driving 105 mph was spared adult prison after a judge considered the circumstances and family pleas. The Michigan Department of Corrections recommended prison, but the judge gave a sentence deemed more lenient. The victim's family expressed distress over the verdict, highlighting the lasting impact of the tragedy on all involved.

stories.headline: Trump keeps control of Guard in L.A.
stories.summary: U.S. District Judge Charles Breyer ruled the president's deployment of the Guard in California unlawful, ordering it to return control to the state. However, appeals courts temporarily blocked this decision. President Trump stated that the Guard remains in his hands and that he saved L.A. by sending them. Immigration efforts also increased, with Marines moving into Los Angeles to support ground efforts against illegal immigration.

stories.headline: Dallas ISD mulls revisions to equity policy
stories.summary: Dallas ISD is reviewing its equity policy amid criticism from state officials and political pressures linked to DEI work. The district adopted a policy in 2018 to address racial equity through specific pledges supporting Black students and Black lives. Trustees are considering revisions to ensure policy compliance and clarity, stating the changes wouldn't represent a departure from district values but aim to ease communication with families.

stories.headline: 'No Kings' protests are planned today
stories.summary: Opponents of President Donald Trump and his administration are set to rally across North Texas, including Dallas, Fort Worth, and Arlington, coinciding with the Army’s 250th anniversary and Trump's birthday. The 'No Kings' protests will focus on federal immigration raids and other grievances related to Trump's policies. Texas Governor Greg Abbott has ordered deployment of over 5,000 Texas National Guard troops to assist with preparations for the protests.

stories.headline: Gateway founder is sued by accuser for defamation
stories.summary: A woman claiming sexual abuse by Gateway Church founder Robert Morris has filed a defamation lawsuit against him, the church, and related parties seeking over $1M. The lawsuit alleges statements categorizing the abuse claims as an 'inappropriate relationship' are defamatory. The accuser and her father seek damages for harm caused by Morris and the church's response to the allegations.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates for strikes
stories.summary: Explosions were heard over Jerusalem and Tel Aviv after an Israeli strike in Tehran, Iran. The blasts targeted Iran's nuclear and military infrastructure. Iran responded by launching ballistic missiles into Israel, prompting citizens to take shelter. Despite the missile attacks, there were no immediate casualties reported. The attacks and retaliation have raised security tensions in the region.

stories.headline: Official: Jail system broken
stories.summary: The Dallas County Jail is facing a crisis of severe overcrowding, with the daily population surpassing 6,900. Officials highlight a need for transformational change, citing a broken system. The jail's condition is deemed a state of emergency by Dallas County officials, while other counties have reduced jail populations by connecting people with mental health issues to better services.

stories.headline: Pa. plays big on sports stage
stories.summary: Pennsylvania tourism officials highlight the significant impact of hosting four major sports events in 2025, including the 125th U.S. Open Championship at Oakmont Country Club. The state expects billions of dollars in economic impact from these regional and national events. The NFL Draft, PGA Championship in Delaware, MLB All-Star Game in Philadelphia, and U.S. Open golf tournament will attract large crowds and national attention to Pennsylvania's sports venues.

stories.headline: Marines on guard at federal buildings
stories.summary: In response to protests following federal immigration raids, about 200 Marines were deployed to Los Angeles to guard federal buildings, with other cities preparing for similar measures. The protests, partly sparked by President Donald Trump's policies, have involved clashes with police and demand heavy security measures. The federal building west of downtown was protected by National Guard and Marine units, ensuring law enforcement presence amid ongoing tensions.

stories.headline: Iran answers Israel's attacks
stories.summary: Iran launched retaliatory attacks on Israel following Israeli strikes on Iranian nuclear and military facilities. The strikes involved warplanes and drones targeting Iranian sites, killing top generals and scientists, as Iran sought to prevent Israel from getting closer to building an atomic weapon. The Israeli military urged civilians to seek shelter as more missiles were fired, signaling escalating conflict in the region.

stories.headline: Security threat resolved
stories.summary: Nippon Steel Corp. announced it signed a national security agreement allowing its $14.9 billion acquisition of U.S. Steel Corp. to proceed as planned. The agreement follows a thorough national security review process and alleviates concerns about potential risks associated with the deal. President Donald Trump signed an executive order allowing the deal to move forward, subject to oversight to mitigate any security concerns raised by the U.S. government.

stories.headline: Farmworkers fearful of raids by ICE
stories.summary: Immigration enforcement activities by ICE have raised fears among farmworkers in California's Central Valley, a region vital to the state's agricultural output. Rumors of immigration raids have spread across counties, though many reports remain unconfirmed. Local authorities and immigrant support organizations are monitoring the situation closely as concerns grow about the impact of potential deportations on workers and the broader community.

stories.headline: Wide wealth gaps for Asian Americans
stories.summary: A new analysis of census data reveals significant income disparities within the Asian American community in the Bay Area, with notable inequality among its different ethnic subgroups. Punjabi Americans, including longtime residents like Jagtar Singh Kang, experience some of the highest levels of income inequality, driven by stagnant wages among the lowest-paid and high income inequality nationwide. This report sheds light on the economic challenges faced by various Asian ethnicities despite broader perceptions of success.

stories.headline: State Farm's handling of fire claims under probe
stories.summary: California regulators have launched an investigation into State Farm General, the state's largest insurer, following public outcry and complaints from survivors of the Los Angeles-area wildfires. The examination will focus on the insurer's handling of policyholder complaints and potential violations of insurance code. State Farm reported significant payouts related to wildfire claims, but regulators are scrutinizing accusations of inconsistent decisions, delayed payments, and inadequate communication with homeowners.

stories.headline: Troops remain in Trump's control
stories.summary: A federal appeals court temporarily blocked a restraining order that sought to limit President Donald Trump's authority over California National Guard troops deployed on the streets of Los Angeles to combat immigration protests. The order was granted by a federal judge but quickly overturned by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The case highlights ongoing legal battles over Trump's use of military forces for domestic law enforcement duties frequently handled by local police.

stories.headline: Handling of Padilla brings swift fallout
stories.summary: Senator Alex Padilla was forcibly removed from a news conference hosted by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, leading to polarized reactions along party lines. Democrats viewed the incident as an escalation of attacks on President Donald Trump's administration, while Republicans criticized Padilla for not properly identifying himself. The altercation involved Secret Service agents restraining Padilla and highlighted tensions over immigration-related issues and enforcement in Los Angeles.

stories.headline: Iran strikes back at Israel with missiles
stories.summary: Israel launched a series of missile attacks on Iran's nuclear and military sites, causing explosions and casualties. Iran retaliated with its own missile strikes on Israel, continuing the escalation. Both sides are enduring ongoing exchanges of attacks, impacting civilians and military targets in the region.

stories.headline: Detroit chases performance renown at Le Mans
stories.summary: Detroit’s automotive manufacturers, including Cadillac, are competing in the prestigious 24 Hours of Le Mans race to enhance their performance reputation. Cadillac secured pole position, showcasing strength against traditional European rivals like Ferrari and Porsche. The race marks a significant opportunity for Detroit to demonstrate its racing and engineering prowess internationally.

stories.headline: 'Misuse' nixes $20M grant
stories.summary: State officials abruptly canceled a $20 million grant for a business development organization due to misuse of funds, including an unreasonable salary and policy failures. The Michigan Economic Development Corporation and attorney for Global Link International CEO Fay Beydoun provided details about the cancellation and state demands for repayment of misused funds.

stories.headline: Michigan U-pick farms ripe with optimism
stories.summary: On a warm June morning, families enjoy picking strawberries and other fruits at Michigan U-pick farms. Farm owners and visitors alike express excitement about the summer season, highlighting how strawberry picking brings the community together and supports local agriculture. This season is seen as particularly special with strong turnout and engagement.

stories.headline: Metro Detroit Jews, Arabs share fears
stories.summary: Jewish and Arab Americans in Metro Detroit express fears of violence after Israeli attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities and retaliatory missile strikes. Local community leaders highlight concerns over increasing tensions and potential violence impacting Israeli attacks on Iranian targets and subsequent counterattacks.

stories.headline: Now Canada looks to limit immigration
stories.summary: Canada is tightening immigration rules as the US cracks down on immigration. The newly elected Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's government plans to introduce legislation that will curb immigration from the US, including measures targeting fentanyl trafficking and organized crime. The move aims to reduce the number of refugees and asylum seekers arriving from the US as protections there decrease. Some critics view this legislation as harsh and discouraging to those seeking asylum in Canada.

stories.headline: Celebrating ideals of democracy
stories.summary: The celebration in downtown Boston on June 17, 1825, honored the city's founders' democratic values with reenactments, music, poetry, and orators. The event marks more than two centuries since the Battle of Bunker Hill and recognizes the contributions of military companies that marched to Charlestown, remembering the Colonial militia 50 years prior. The crowds celebrated with a bazaar, food, music, and wine as the 18-year project of building the Bunker Hill Monument nears completion.

stories.headline: Descendants take pride in their ties to Bunker Hill
stories.summary: Matt Woodfin, a 32-year-old from Charlestown, tracing his ties to Henry Dearborn through an old family sword, and other descendants gathered to commemorate the bravery of their ancestors who fought at the Battle of Bunker Hill 250 years ago. The event honors over 50 descendants and Bunker Hill veterans with stories and celebrations that celebrate the sacrifice their ancestors made during the American Revolutionary War.

stories.headline: Iran strikes back at Israel as leaders ratchet up rhetoric
stories.summary: Iran fired missiles at Israel after Israel's largest attack against Iran, hitting nuclear sites and killing many military personnel and scientists. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu called it a last resort to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons. Iran's Supreme Leader Khamenei claimed the attacks would last days. Israel struck back with dozens of missiles targeting Iran’s military and defense sites. The conflict escalated with casualties reported on both sides amid rising tensions and strong rhetoric.

stories.headline: Marines in place in LA; cities get set for rallies
stories.summary: About 200 Marines have moved into Los Angeles to guard a federal building amid ongoing large-scale protests against President Trump's policies. The Marine troops, equipped with rifles and combat gear, complement National Guard members deployed to the city after recent protests. Their role is protection, not law enforcement, and they are replacing some National Guard soldiers assigned to civil disturbance duties. Protests have sparked clashes around the country, leading to multiple arrests.

stories.headline: Israel strikes Iran's nuclear sites, faces return barrages
stories.summary: Israel launched blistering attacks on Iran's nuclear and military sites using warplanes and drones. Iran retaliated with ballistic missile launches targeting Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, causing explosions and alarms. The conflict escalated with sirens and attacks possibly involving Iranian drones linked to the paramilitary Revolutionary Guard.

stories.headline: Russian forces expand fighting to new region of Ukraine
stories.summary: In a new offensive, Russian forces have entered the Dnipropetrovsk region in eastern Ukraine, marking expansion beyond the Donetsk area. Small Russian squads reportedly engaged Ukrainian officers, showcasing ongoing and strategic military advances amid the conflict. Although Russia signals no intent to seize the new region, efforts aim to disrupt Ukrainian morale and fortify defenses ahead of anticipated fighting.

stories.headline: Riders revisit the point of no return
stories.summary: Cherokee Nation members and Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians cyclists took part in a 950-mile Trail of Tears event retracing their ancestors' forced removal route. The journey commemorates the suffering endured during the 1838-39 forced marches that are now known as the Trail of Tears. The event fosters reflection on the painful legacy of Cherokee displacement.

stories.headline: Trump's order on voter ID blocked
stories.summary: A federal judge sided with states that sued to prevent new stringent voter ID laws proposed by President Donald Trump via executive order. The ruling blocked key aspects of Trump's efforts to overhaul election laws regarding proof of citizenship for voting. The judge's order stayed in place amid concerns it exceeded presidential authority and risked disenfranchisement of voters.

stories.headline: Trump, Despite Promises, Discovers Peace Is Elusive
stories.summary: President Trump entered the last day of his term without achieving the hoped-for peace deal in the Middle East, despite earlier promises and a successful initial strike on Iranian targets. The escalating conflict and political disagreements both domestically and internationally have hindered progress. Analysts suggest that Trump’s political base and opposition have complicated efforts to achieve peace, with the situation remaining unstable as Iran vows retaliation.

stories.headline: Iran Retaliates After Israeli Attack
stories.summary: Israel and Iran traded attacks on Friday after Israeli planes and drones targeted Tehran's nuclear program and military leadership. Iran retaliated by firing missiles at Tel Aviv, prompting accusations that Israel started the conflict. The Iranian missile strikes caused injuries and destruction, with Israel intercepting most of the missiles fired. The Israeli military confirmed launching dozens of retaliatory missiles from Iran controlling forces as tensions escalate in the region.

stories.headline: Stocks Fall Sharply As Oil Prices Surge
stories.summary: Stocks plunged sharply after Israel launched an attack on Iran's nuclear facilities and military leadership, leading to fears of a wider war in the Middle East. This escalation caused increased volatility in global energy flows, with oil prices rising sharply alongside investor concerns about potential disruption to supply. The geopolitical tensions have unsettled markets as investors brace for the economic consequences.

stories.headline: Walmart, Amazon Are Exploring Issuing Stablecoins of Their Own
stories.summary: Major multinational retailers Walmart and Amazon are exploring the concept of issuing their own stablecoins to facilitate payments and reduce transaction fees. This move aims to bypass traditional payment systems by utilizing blockchain technology to offer customers and employees a novel form of digital currency. The exploration reflects rising interest in cryptocurrency and the potential for large corporations to innovate in financial services.

stories.headline: Muppets Superfans Cry It Out As Their Happy Place Goes Dark
stories.summary: The closure of the Disney attraction Muppet*Vision 3D in Orlando drew emotional reactions from longtime fans who had grown nostalgic about the experience. Beloved characters like Kermit and Fozzie Bear, along with the quirky humor of the show, made the attraction a special place for many visitors. The shutdown marks the end of an era for fans who had formed a strong bond with this Disney feature for decades.

stories.headline: The Man in Seat 11A: He Walked Away From Air India Crash
stories.summary: In the aftermath of a devastating Air India crash, one man seated in 11A survived without serious harm and was able to walk away from the wreckage. The crash involved a massive fireball and thick smoke as the plane went down, but the survivor was lucky to escape with minor injuries. Investigators continue to recover the black boxes and analyze the causes of the crash while mourners remember those lost.

stories.headline: Trump cuts endanger Iowa public media role
stories.summary: Federal funding cuts proposed by President Donald Trump could significantly impact Iowa public media programs such as PBS and Iowa Public Radio. The executive order aims to reduce government funding of news media, potentially endangering weather systems and rural access services. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting's funding, totaling $1.1 billion, may be affected, putting local stations at risk, especially in an economic recession. The proposal is now under Senate review with urgent appeal from public media leaders to support local stations' viability.

stories.headline: Aging buildings, new alarm bells
stories.summary: Several buildings in Des Moines, including a Victorian house, a school, and others, were listed among the most endangered buildings in the city for 2025 due to risk of demolition or irreparable damage. The annual list aims to raise awareness to preserve historic local structures that contribute to the city's unique character and charm. Notable buildings on the list include the Ulysses S. Grant School and properties on Forest Avenue and 23rd Street. Efforts are underway to protect these landmarks and maintain vibrant, authentic destinations in Des Moines.

stories.headline: Big 12 unveils league schedule for Iowa State women's hoops
stories.summary: The Big 12 announced the league schedule for the Iowa State women's basketball team, outlining dates and opponents for the upcoming season. This release helps fans and stakeholders prepare for the team's competitive season and promotes engagement with the sport and university.

stories.headline: Iran hits Israel with missiles, drones amid calls for calm
stories.summary: Iran launched retaliatory missile and drone attacks on Israel targets on June 13 after Israel's attacks in bomb shelters. Over 100 rockets were reportedly fired from Iran with one building in Ovaz hit, alongside others. Israeli officials reported five people injured moderately and four with light shrapnel wounds. Despite the violence, both Iran and world leaders called for calming the conflict to avoid further escalation.

stories.headline: Raid fear revives 'notario' scheme
stories.summary: Authorities are warning of scammers posing as immigration lawyers to exploit vulnerable people, particularly in light of increased immigration raids. The article highlights a victim's story of being scammed through such schemes involving false promises to secure immigration papers.

stories.headline: City braces for 'No Kings' protests
stories.summary: At least a dozen groups are planning protests against the Trump administration's immigration raids in Los Angeles and other major cities. The demonstrations aim to voice opposition to federal policies with events organized by groups including Indivisible and the American Civil Liberties Union. Authorities are preparing for widespread demonstrations expected Saturday.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates after Israel's attack
stories.summary: Iran launched successive missile barrages on Israel in retaliation for an Israeli campaign that destroyed parts of its nuclear and military infrastructure. The exchanges heightened fears of a full-scale regional conflict potentially involving the U.S. Broadcasts from Tel Aviv showed damage to residential buildings, raising tensions between the two countries in the Middle East.

stories.headline: L.A. police chief, sheriff walk a fine line
stories.summary: Amid immigration debates and protests, L.A. police and sheriff leadership navigates complex community dynamics. They support enforcing immigration laws but acknowledge diverse community feelings and the importance of measured law enforcement approaches.

stories.headline: Polarized reactions to Padilla incident
stories.summary: Following federal agents' detention of Senator Alex Padilla, Republicans chastise him while Democrats call for an investigation. The incident and subsequent responses highlight partisan divisions on immigration enforcement and political accountability.

stories.headline: As different as night and day
stories.summary: Amid rising protests against immigration raids in Los Angeles, a contrast is seen between calm daytime and rising evening tensions. Protesters, including high school students, engage in demonstrations expressing their opposition to federal immigration actions. The piece explores the dynamics of the protests and the varied responses on city streets.

stories.headline: Rural Medicaid recipients risk losing coverage
stories.summary: The U.S. Senate is considering a bill proposed by President Donald Trump to cut more than $720 billion in Medicaid spending nationwide, potentially impacting over 400,000 rural Marylanders and others who rely on the program. The bill could severely affect vulnerable populations who depend on Medicaid, especially in rural communities. Advocates express concern about losing health coverage amid ongoing health challenges.

stories.headline: 200 Marines begin their deployment in Los Angeles
stories.summary: Two hundred Marines were seen standing guard outside a federal building in Los Angeles as they started their deployment to manage protests and immigration-related unrest. Their presence marks a significant federal involvement in maintaining order during ongoing demonstrations.

stories.headline: Jury deliberations begin in Severna Park abuse trial
stories.summary: Jury deliberations have commenced in a high-profile abuse trial involving Matthew Schlegel, a suspended elementary school teacher accused of inappropriate touching of students. The trial captured community attention given the serious nature of the allegations.

stories.headline: 3 Md. men plead guilty to $550M bribery scheme
stories.summary: Three Maryland men pleaded guilty to a major bribery and fake bribery scheme involving at least 14 federal contracts worth more than $550 million over ten years. The case exposes significant corruption and misuse of federal resources in Maryland.

stories.headline: Abrego Garcia pleads not guilty to human smuggling
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Republican construction worker, pled not guilty to human smuggling charges. The case relates to a garnishment order previously issued in Tennessee. The hearing represents a critical step in ongoing investigations linked to human smuggling and immigration enforcement under the current administration.

stories.headline: How police, city keeping the peace at ICE protests
stories.summary: As anti-ICE protests in Los Angeles intensify with frequent curfews, the National Guard and Marines have been deployed to help maintain order. Demonstrations have been both chaotic and peaceful, with law enforcement aiming to prevent violence and property damage. Protesters have voiced their demands forcefully, while dialogue and efforts to avoid escalation continue behind the scenes.

stories.headline: Speaking out on juvenile crime
stories.summary: With new leadership at the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, residents and officials express increased focus on improving juvenile justice. The department faces rising juvenile crime rates and challenges like funding, facilities, and public trust. Efforts include focus on prevention, rehabilitation, and community engagement to better address youth crime and recidivism in Baltimore and Maryland statewide.

stories.headline: Administration gives personal data of immigrant Medicaid enrollees to deportation officials
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's administration issued a directive to share personal data, including immigration status, of millions of Medicaid enrollees with deportation officials. This move has raised serious privacy and ethical concerns, potentially affecting vulnerable immigrant populations relying on Medicaid. Legal challenges have arisen and advocacy groups warn about the consequences of sharing health information with immigration authorities.

stories.headline: Iran launches barrage of missiles in retaliation
stories.summary: Iran launched a large-scale missile barrage targeting Israel, including attacks on Tehran and Tel Aviv, after an Israeli strike. The barrage involved sophisticated missiles and drones aimed at strategic facilities, killing top figures and civilians. The situation has escalated tensions in the region, with the U.S. and Israel responding diplomatically and militarily. Casualties and damage have been reported with an uncertain outlook on further conflict.

stories.headline: Kids treated to Bible school and supplies
stories.summary: The Beltline Church of Christ hosted its fifth annual Oak Park Boys and Girls Club one-day vacation Bible school and school supply giveaway. The event brought children together to receive needed school essentials and engage in educational and faith-based activities.

stories.headline: Bethune, Fenn dominant in W. Limestone softball
stories.summary: Lilly Bethune, named Decatur Daily's Class 1A-4A softball Player of the Year, closed her high school career with an impressive .541 batting average, 31 home runs, and 91 RBIs. Along with coach Molly Fenn, who was named Class 1A-4A Coach of the Year, they led their team to a 44-7 record and scored 445 runs, establishing a dominant presence in West Limestone softball.

stories.headline: City revenue up more than 5% at midyear
stories.summary: Decatur's fiscal 2025 general fund revenue increased by 5.58% compared to last year, according to Chief Financial Officer Kyle Demeester. This growth was highlighted in a midyear budget review during the Decatur City Council meeting. The positive revenue trend reflects more paving and other expenditures. The council will consider budget adjustments including $1.82 million in additional expenses during the upcoming meeting. Officials noted the city's economic health is solid with strong sales of essentials.

stories.headline: 'Family is the reason for everything'
stories.summary: Orlando Aviles balances running two businesses and family life, highlighting the importance of family as the driving force behind his perseverance and success. He emphasizes that family provides strength and motivation, especially for his three young daughters. Having immigrated to Decatur with his family, Orlando cherishes the value of family in Mexican culture and how it influences his values and goals.

stories.headline: Mack and Stisher take charge
stories.summary: Torry Mack and Eric Stisher were sworn in as Decatur's new police chief and deputy chief respectively. Both men have long military backgrounds, having served in the U.S. Army, and they bring two decades of community and police experience. They aim to use their combined expertise to serve and strengthen the Decatur community, continuing their dedication to public safety.

stories.headline: Israel strikes Iran nuclear sites, generals
stories.summary: Israel launched blistering attacks on the heart of Iran's nuclear and military infrastructure, retaliating after Iran fired a barrage of missiles. The military strikes targeted key nuclear sites and generals, escalating tensions between the nations.

stories.headline: Israel strikes Iran's nuclear sites
stories.summary: Israel launched missile strikes on Iran's nuclear and military sites as retaliation for previous aggression, raising concerns about an all-out war and greater upheaval in the Middle East. Iran fired retaliatory missiles towards Israel but no immediate casualties were reported. Israel's paramedic services reported wounded civilians from the barrage. The situation heightens regional tensions, with Israel warning of clear danger to its survival and Iran vowing revenge.

stories.headline: New board members help in passing HISD's $2.1B budget
stories.summary: Houston ISD's newly appointed board members played a crucial role in passing the district's $2.1 billion budget for the 2025-26 school year, supporting Superintendent Mike Miles' reforms. The four new members shifted the board's stance and approved the budget unanimously, overcoming prior opposition. This change could help speed up district initiatives and improve responsiveness, impacting Houston's education landscape positively.

stories.headline: Autopsy is unable to find cause of teen's death
stories.summary: The autopsy report for a former Houston ISD middle school student who died on campus in August could not definitively determine the cause of death. While the student had a medical emergency in the school gym, no clear cause was found. The death occurred after suffering from a medical emergency, and the family might pursue a lawsuit against Houston ISD. The situation highlights ongoing concerns about campus safety and medical response.

stories.headline: Jury gives man death in killing of officer
stories.summary: A Harris County jury sentenced Salvadoran man Oscar Rosales to death for killing a Precinct 5 deputy constable in Houston's Chinatown. The jury deliberated for nine hours over two days. Rosales was found guilty last week of capital murder for the shooting death of Cpl. Charles Galloway during a 2022 traffic stop. The decision reflects the serious nature of the crime and the jury's conclusion that Rosales poses future danger to others.

stories.headline: Official: If protesters turn violent, ‘we will kill you, graveyard dead’
stories.summary: Florida officials warned residents that violent protests will not be tolerated and threatened arrests and even death for those who become violent in the state. Attorney General James Uthmeier joined other law enforcement leaders in a press conference in Titusville emphasizing swift action against any rioting. Brevard County Sheriff Wayne Ivey added a stark warning that any attack on deputies could result in deadly force and a fierce response.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates for ‘preemptive’ Israel attack
stories.summary: Iran’s state media reported that Iran launched two waves of missiles at Israeli targets following Israeli strikes on June 13 and warned it intended to intercept any Israeli threat. Explosions were heard near Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, with Iranian media confirming attacks on Israeli warplanes and a pilot being taken prisoner. Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei issued a statement amid escalating tensions.

stories.headline: MorseLife residents decry 15% rent hike
stories.summary: Residents at MorseLife in West Palm Beach are protesting a 15% rent increase they say they cannot afford, leading to fears some will be forced to move out. This rent hike coincides with revelations from a Palm Beach Post investigation showing millions of dollars have been paid annually to top MorseLife executives, sparking outrage among residents, donors, and community leaders.

stories.headline: Some new FL insurers fail financial stress test
stories.summary: Since the Florida property insurance market nearly became a catastrophe a few years ago, 12 new insurers arrived to help Floridians weather hurricane season. However, the state announced the failure of a financial fitness test for seven of these new insurers. While regulators will not disclose which companies failed, they noted the continued challenges of the insurance market despite legislative efforts to stabilize it.

stories.headline: Trump urges Iran to accept agreement
stories.summary: Following Israel's missile strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, former President Donald Trump has urged Iran to accept a new agreement. The conflict escalated after Israel attacked multiple sites in Iran, including uranium enrichment facilities, with Iran responding by shooting down an Israeli warplane and taking its pilot prisoner. Iran's Supreme Leader declared that Israel initiated the conflict, warning against hit-and-run tactics, as international agencies confirm damage and elevated radiation levels at the Natanz nuclear site.

stories.headline: 'No Kings' demonstrations occurring across Indiana
stories.summary: 'No Kings' protests are scheduled across Indiana on June 14, coinciding with a massive military parade in Washington, D.C. The movement opposes authoritarianism and emphasizes nonviolent activism. Demonstrators reject symbols of monarchy, including crowns and thrones, in a nationwide challenge to military and political power displays. Over 30 events will take place statewide, promoting the message of anti-authoritarianism and fighting for democracy.

stories.headline: Morales trips' shielded
stories.summary: Indiana lawmakers have passed a measure exempting Secretary of State Diego Morales from disclosing details of his overseas trips, citing their economic development relevance. This move shields him from having to reveal who paid for the trips and other specifics, despite prior questions about his personal trip to Hungary and events involving political fundraising. The legislation prevents state auditors and officials from requiring such disclosures, with upcoming elections highlighting the bill's timing.

stories.headline: Higher education budget advances with major cuts for two schools
stories.summary: The Michigan House of Representatives approved sweeping funding cuts for most state public universities in its budget, targeting major funding cuts to Michigan State University and the University of Michigan. The $2.2 billion budget passed largely along party lines, with Republicans in favor and Democrats opposed. Cuts range from 5.1% to 91.6% of current funding across 15 universities. Budget sponsor Greg Markkanen aims to redistribute money among all public universities despite concerns about the negative impact on the targeted schools.

stories.headline: Tipped worker wage law could face voter referendum
stories.summary: Michigan voters may decide whether tipped workers should receive minimum wage after lawmakers thwarted a change earlier this year. A committee called Voters to Stop Pay Cuts plans to collect signatures to hold a referendum on the February law that increases but preserves the subminimum wage for tipped workers, while accelerating the state’s minimum wage hike to $15 an hour. Officials aim to submit enough signatures by early fall to trigger a voter referendum in November 2026.

stories.headline: Trump's treatment of colleges? 56% of Americans disapprove.
stories.summary: A majority of U.S. adults disapprove of President Donald Trump's handling of issues related to colleges and universities, according to a new poll. More than half of Americans disapprove of the Republican president's approach to higher ed policies, including his administration's frozen federal funding to some schools and demands for broad policy changes. The poll highlights concerns over liberalism, antisemitism, and Trump's impact on scientific research and university autonomy.

stories.headline: Property manager, owners accused of misleading older tenants
stories.summary: A large-scale property manager in Washington is accused in a lawsuit of misleading tenants aged 55 and older by misrepresenting apartment quality and failing to disclose rent impacts. The state alleges violations of consumer protection laws at five properties owned by Vintage Housing and FPI Management. The company denies allegations and intends to address them in court.

stories.headline: Emergency plan in works after 14M bees escaped truck
stories.summary: After 14 million bees escaped from a truck in Whatcom County, emergency plans are being developed to manage the situation. Tom Ferry and other beekeepers worked to contain the escaped bees using various methods including wrapped strips on limbs and ankles. The incident poses potential risks to the community but efforts are underway to ensure safety and recapture of the bees.

stories.headline: Racing against Trump's travel ban: Afghan man reunites with family after years of separation
stories.summary: An Afghan man named Ahmadi successfully reunited with his family at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport after years apart due to President Trump's travel ban affecting Afghan nationals. Despite the ban complicating travel, Ahmadi's family was able to join him after legal and administrative hurdles were overcome. The story highlights the human impact of immigration policies.

stories.headline: Iran fires on Israel in retaliation, killing 2
stories.summary: In response to Israeli airstrikes as Trump urges Iran to 'make a deal,' Iran launched missile strikes on Israel, killing at least two people and injuring others. The conflict escalated with airstrikes, drone attacks, and missile fire with both sides taking casualties and causing damage. The situation remains tense with ongoing military exchanges.

stories.headline: Air India 787 crash, deadliest in a decade, shakes aerospace industry
stories.summary: The Air India Dreamliner crash killed at least 241 people, prompting an inquiry and suspension of public events related to the Paris Air Show. Investigations from India continue with support from the U.S. and U.K. as Boeing executives cancel air show plans. The crash is the worst in a decade and has shaken the aerospace sector.

stories.headline: Penn doctors complete rare double hand transplant for Swiss man
stories.summary: Doctors at the University of Pennsylvania successfully performed a rare double hand transplant on 29-year-old Luka Krizanac from Switzerland. Krizanac had lost both hands due to a life-threatening infection when he was 12. The transplant surgery aims to restore his ability to write, drink coffee, and perform daily tasks. This complex procedure involved coordination with Orthoplastic Limb Salvage Center specialists.

stories.headline: Black box recovered from Air India crash
stories.summary: The flight data recorder from the crashed Air India flight was recovered to provide clues about the cause of the accident, which killed 241 people. The airplane, a Boeing 787, had crashed shortly after takeoff from an airport in Ahmedabad. Investigations are ongoing, with experts analyzing engine and control system data. The probe is being conducted by Indian aviation authorities with technical guidance from the U.K. and the U.S.

stories.headline: Montco officials change jail detainer policy
stories.summary: Montgomery County jail officials have changed their policy on holding immigrants wanted by ICE after posting bail, ending a practice that allowed federal agents to arrest people who might have otherwise been freed. The change follows a recent case where a woman was held beyond her bail for ICE. Officials hope this policy change will reduce ICE detainer cases, though it affects many in immigration detention or deportation processes.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates after Israel hits nuclear sites
stories.summary: Israel launched airstrikes on Iran's nuclear and military sites on Friday, with the attack being Israel's largest warplane operation in recent years. Iran responded by launching missile attacks on Israeli cities including Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, causing explosions and air defense responses, though there were no immediate reports of casualties. This escalation is part of ongoing hostilities between the two countries.

stories.headline: Deportation officials are provided with Medicaid data
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's administration has provided deportation officials with access to Medicaid data to identify undocumented immigrants. An internal memo shows officials used this information to block immigration benefits and compliance with legal and ethical concerns. This data transfer has raised questions about privacy, health records use, and enforcement in Southern California and beyond.

stories.headline: Crash remnants
stories.summary: Parts of an Air India plane crashed on Thursday are shown near a building in Ahmedabad, India, on Friday. The crash has caused significant damage and is under investigation. Authorities are looking into the cause and impact of the disaster.

stories.headline: Marines take posts at buildings in LA
stories.summary: Marines have been deployed to stand guard outside a federal building in Los Angeles, replacing National Guard members who were originally deployed after recent protests and immigration raids. The deployment of around 700 Marines is intended to provide security and free up other law enforcement resources. The Marines are wearing combat gear and stationed at entrance points of the building.

stories.headline: Womack revives bill to allow ban on defiling flag
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Steve Womack reintroduced legislation aiming to amend the Constitution to prohibit burning or desecration of the American flag. Despite the Supreme Court's recognition of desecration as constitutionally protected free speech, Womack and others seek to create an amendment to restrict this form of expression, continuing efforts spanning more than three decades.

stories.headline: Market tumbles after Iran attack
stories.summary: Oil prices surged and stock markets fell due to fears of escalating violence after Iran's nuclear facilities were attacked. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped, reflecting concerns over disruptions in global oil supply and the wider economic impact. Brent crude oil prices jumped over 7%, highlighting market uncertainty amid geopolitical tensions.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates after strikes
stories.summary: Israel launched attacks on Iran's nuclear and military sites, deploying warplanes and drones to assault key facilities. Iran responded with ballistic missile strikes aimed at Israeli air defense systems to intercept incoming projectiles. The strikes caused injuries and damage, with one woman reported in severe condition. The conflict stems from escalating violence following Israel's actions against Iran's nuclear and military targets.

stories.headline: Roadblocks arise as city attempts to hire deputy city manager
stories.summary: Santa Fe City Manager Mark Scott faces delays in hiring a new deputy city manager due to a 60-day hiring limitation and a city council resolution that may affect the timeline. Scott describes the hiring limitation as 'nonsensical.' The current deputy, Alann Webber, has an expiring term, and the city council is considering dropping the time limit from the city charter to facilitate the hiring process.

stories.headline: Senate aims to boost redress for radiation victims
stories.summary: A proposed provision in Trump's tax bill seeks to extend compensation coverage to individuals 'downwind' of nuclear tests, expanding benefits under the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act. This legislation would apply to victims affected primarily by the Trinity Site blast, among others, providing support for serious illnesses caused by nuclear testing and manufacturing. The amendment addresses previous limitations and aims to cover a broader range of illnesses.

stories.headline: Israel hails its successes, but strategic aims elusive
stories.summary: In response to Israel's surprise attack on Iran nuclear sites, analysts warn of the potential for a broader conflict. Despite Israel's operational successes, Prime Minister Netanyahu did not appear celebratory. The attack targeted Iran's nuclear facility at Natanz and involved a covert Mossad operation. The incident has intensified geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, with Iran sustaining significant damage and casualties among senior military leaders.

stories.headline: Getting a 'bird's-eye view'
stories.summary: Employers of New Mexico National Guard troops experience military life firsthand aboard a Black Hawk helicopter. The flight, based at the National Guard Santa Fe Readiness Center, was an opportunity for civilian employers to understand the routines and challenges faced by National Guard members. Participants described the flight as memorable and exciting, providing insight into military service.

stories.headline: CYFD slammed after death of infant
stories.summary: New Mexico's Attorney General and GOP lawmakers harshly criticize the decision to assign a grandmother with monitoring the safety of a baby exposed to drugs. The infant, known only as 'C.M.,' was found unresponsive several days after a nap with parents in Albuquerque. Both adults in the home were found to consistently use drugs. The grandmother was tasked with ensuring the infant's safety, a practice now under scrutiny following the baby's death.

stories.headline: Victims’ relatives: Teen accused in Chelsea slayings had mental issues
stories.summary: Following a double murder in Chelsea, Maine, a 16-year-old has been charged with the killings. Relatives of the victims report the suspect had a history of mental health issues. State Police continue to process evidence at the scene, collecting items such as plastic tubs and biohazard material. Family members described the impact of the event and the youth's struggles, while authorities investigate the case further.

stories.headline: THC-infused drinks seeped past a loophole; Maine lawmakers act to limit sales to minors
stories.summary: Maine lawmakers are moving to limit sales of THC-infused beverages, which previously proliferated due to lack of regulation. These low-dose psychoactive drinks, made from delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol derived from hemp, have become popular in convenience stores and craft breweries. The legislation aims to address potential risks by imposing restrictions akin to alcohol and tobacco sales, as oversight was minimal in recent years.

stories.headline: Rep. Pingree admits she violated law over financial disclosures
stories.summary: Rep. Chellie Pingree acknowledged violating the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act by failing to disclose a sizable purchase of U.S. Treasury securities made in February. The disclosure lapse meant financial transactions worth between $90,000 and $300,000 were not publicly reported in a timely manner. Pingree cited a paperwork error and has since rectified the issue and filed a proper disclosure.

stories.headline: City’s revaluation results are in — homeowners aren’t happy
stories.summary: Some homeowners in Portland report their home values have skyrocketed since the last property revaluation in 2021, despite having fewer amenities and not making major updates. Many feel their property taxes will increase significantly, causing dissatisfaction among long-term residents. The city mandated a reassessment every five years to ensure more equitable property value distribution.

stories.headline: Walz tries to strike balance in thorny politics of immigration
stories.summary: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz addresses the complex immigration issues facing the state and country, balancing different political pressures and controversies. In Washington, discussions continue about the federal immigration system, with Walz advocating for a measured approach. The political landscape includes clashes over immigration enforcement and humanitarian concerns amid ongoing national debates.

stories.headline: Klobuchar heads to N.H. amid speculation over her ambitions
stories.summary: Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar is heading to New Hampshire amidst speculation about a possible run for president in 2028. While she has not confirmed intentions, political strategists note her potential candidacy and leadership within the Democratic Party. Klobuchar aims to connect with voters and party members in the early primary state to build momentum for a possible long-term political campaign.

stories.headline: Immigrant driver could face aggravated sentence
stories.summary: Hennepin County Attorney Mary Moriarty's office plans to seek an aggravated sentence for an undocumented immigrant woman convicted of criminal charges related to driving while intoxicated in a case linked to the Trump administration's immigration policies. The involved parties argue that the driver's conduct endangered others, prompting calls for stricter punishments under state guidelines, despite concerns about the broader immigration context.

stories.headline: Tensions rise as meatpacking town steels itself for potential ICE raids
stories.summary: In Worthington, Minnesota, the community is on edge ahead of possible Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids targeting immigrant workers in the local meatpacking plant. Families fear detentions and deportations, leading to worry and mobilization among residents. The town is grappling with concerns about immigration enforcement, community safety, and the potential for widespread disruption.

stories.headline: Guard to stay in L.A. while case is challenged
stories.summary: A federal appeals court in San Francisco paused an order requiring the National Guard to relinquish control, after a judge ruled that President Trump had illegally seized command of up to 4,000 National Guard troops in California. The troops had been deployed to protect immigration agents and federal buildings amidst protests. The Trump administration challenged the ruling and sought to maintain the deployment while litigation proceeds.

stories.headline: Fear becomes fixture in Worthington
stories.summary: Tensions in Worthington, Minnesota are rising amid fears of potential Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raids. Families, including that of a young girl named Katie, are deeply worried about forced deportations as federal government actions intensify. The local community, comprised largely of immigrant workers in meatpacking plants, braces for the impact of heightened immigration enforcement. The anxiety about raids and possible family separations is pervasive, leading to community protests and political actions.

stories.headline: Iran retaliates against Israel
stories.summary: Iran launched missile barrages in response to Israeli strikes on nuclear and military structures. The attacks involved ballistic missiles, drones, and explosions, targeting Israeli locations including Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. The Iranian Revolutionary Guard claimed responsibility, asserting that scores of missiles were launched following Israeli attacks. The situation has raised concerns over escalating tensions and casualties, with Hezbollah and allied groups also implicated in related conflicts. Analysts fear the broader Middle East may see disruption in energy supplies and increased geopolitical instability.
